semantic_title: Present on Admission (POA) Indicator Assignment for Same Diagnosis Code Covering Multiple Conditions
section_path: Present on Admission Reporting Guidelines > Same Diagnosis Code for Two or More Conditions

content.full_text: When the same ICD-10-CM diagnosis code applies to two or more conditions during the same encounter (e.g., two separate conditions classified to the same ICD-10-CM diagnosis code): Assign 'Y' if all conditions represented by the single ICD-10-CM code were present on admission (e.g., bilateral unspecified age-related cataracts). Assign 'N' if any of the conditions represented by the single ICD-10-CM code was not present on admission (e.g. traumatic secondary and recurrent hemorrhage and seroma is assigned to a single code T79.2, but only one of the conditions was present on admission). (Evidence: pg no: 120, L5-L11)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assign 'Y' if all conditions represented by the single ICD-10-CM code were present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L8-L9)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple conditions are classified to the same code, POA indicator 'Y' is only appropriate if every condition represented by that code was present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L8-L9)
common_applications: Bilateral conditions classified to single code
Multiple related conditions under one code

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assign 'N' if any of the conditions represented by the single ICD-10-CM code was not present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L10-L11)
detailed_rules.explanation: If even one condition represented by the code was not present on admission, the entire code receives POA indicator 'N' (Evidence: pg no: 120, L10-L11)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify that single ICD-10-CM code represents multiple conditions
Step 2: Determine admission status of each individual condition
Step 3: Assign 'Y' only if ALL conditions were present on admission
Step 4: Assign 'N' if ANY condition was not present on admission
